title: George McWilliams
text:
George Frederick McWilliams (10 November 1865 – 12 February 1907) was an Australian doctor, <a href="military%20surgeon">military surgeon</a>, and politician. He served as a member of the <a href="Western%20Australian%20Legislative%20Assembly">Legislative Assembly</a> of <a href="Western%20Australia">Western Australia</a> from 1901 to 1904, representing the <a href="Electoral%20district%20of%20North%20Perth">seat of North Perth</a>.
Early life.
McWilliams was born near <a href="Geelong">Geelong</a>, <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a>, to Anne (née Toohey) and Wilson McWilliams. He was sent to school in England, but returned to Australia to study at the <a href="University%20of%20Melbourne">University of Melbourne</a>, graduating with a medical degree (<a href="Bachelor%20of%20Medicine">M.B.</a>) in 1888. McWilliams left for Western Australia later that year, initially practising medicine in <a href="York%2C%20Western%20Australia">York</a>. He later spent time in the <a href="North-West%20Australia">North-West</a>, working for periods as a <a href="pearler">pearler</a> and a <a href="Stockman%20%28Australia%29">stockman</a>, before moving to <a href="Perth">Perth</a> to establish his own practice. With <a href="Mathieson%20Jacoby">Mathieson Jacoby</a>, McWilliams helped to found the state branch of the <a href="St%20John%20Ambulance%20Australia">St John Ambulance</a>, and served as the inaugural president.
Military and political service.
During the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a>, McWilliams volunteered with the <a href="West%20Australian%20Mounted%20Infantry">West Australian Mounted Infantry</a>, serving as the contingent's chief medical officer. He began the war with the rank of <a href="Captain%20%28armed%20forces%29">captain</a>, and was subsequently promoted <a href="major">major</a> and then lieutenant-colonel, returning to Australia in late 1900. McWilliams entered parliament at the <a href="1901%20North%20Perth%20state%20by-election">1901 North Perth by-election</a>, which had been caused by the death of <a href="Richard%20Speight">Richard Speight</a> after only a few months in office. In April 1902, McWilliams was selected to represent Australia at the <a href="Coronation%20of%20King%20Edward%20VII%20and%20Queen%20Alexandra">coronation of Edward VII</a> in London, as the leader of the contingent from Western Australia. He returned to Australia in October 1902, but did not recontest his seat at the <a href="1904%20Western%20Australian%20state%20election">1904 state election</a>.
Later life.
After leaving parliament, McWilliams was appointed to the board of the <a href="Royal%20Perth%20Hospital">Perth Hospital</a>. Unmarried, he died in Perth in February 1907, aged 41, from complications of <a href="gastroenteritis">gastroenteritis</a>. He was buried at <a href="Karrakatta%20Cemetery">Karrakatta Cemetery</a> with full military honours, with the service conducted by the <a href="Anglican%20Diocese%20of%20Perth">Bishop of Perth</a>, <a href="Charles%20Riley">Charles Riley</a>.
